tags: you can all come at me
do i think this movie is bad?
but that doesnt change the fact that it is disappointing
in terms of what it wants to achieve
summary: Your comment on Captain Marvel is disappointing. You must be proud that we have a female superhero as lead. Unfollowing.
question: Your comment on Captain Marvel is disappointing. You must be proud that we have a female superhero as lead. Unfollowing.
answer:
Other than having a strong female character as a superhero, what else does Captain Marvel offer as an innovative storytelling?

Carol Danvers is badass. She can punch you to your death. She is charming. She is powerful beyond approach. Her main (and perhaps her only) point of reckoning in the story is to remember that she is indeed, powerful. Symbolically, that may mean something but in terms of narrative level, that’s bland. It’s wanting. We don’t get to see the complexity of who she is, that she is more than just a powerful jock who can outpunch other superheroes. Her backstory, her growth, lacks emotional pull. Her growth is not internal. She is born badass, so there’s no point in growing other than remembering that she is that. An essentialist take on “femalehood” like what was shown in this movie is as harmful as any misogynist claim of what “femalehood” or “womanhood” is. In all this, where exactly is Carol Danvers? Or are we supposed to project ourselves to her yet again?

I’m disappointed because I thought we are beyond this notion that female characters are strong mainly because they can kick some ass. In wanting to communicate symbolism, the storyline has to flatten a female character yet again. Brie Larson is a competent actress, and she did elevate the script by being herself. Yet, the story is too scattered and most of the inspiring aspects of the movie are simply two step away from being awesome. I want more than female leads in my superhero stories. What I want are competently written characters, no matter what role they take.

Before you accused me of not getting this movie at all, I understand the message: We, women, are born strong. Sometimes we forget that part of ourselves because we are silenced by men, we make ourselves believe that we are weak. As Danvers finally remembers who she is, we also must remember that we are also born powerful. I get it. My main disappointment is that you can make this kind of symbolism without having to sacrifice the complexity of your female lead.

If only the presentation of the story is less lackadaisical, if it has tighter script, if the fighting scenes are more innovative, I would not be as disappointed as I am now.

Again, tell me, other than having a superhero whose sole personality is being so powerful, what else does Captain Marvel offer?

title: Brianna Wu Calls for Government Legislation In Response to Negative Captain Marvel Reviews
body:
Brianna Wu Calls for Government Legislation In Response to Negative Captain Marvel Reviews

In last year’s Midterm race for seats in the United States House of Representatives, Anti-GamerGate personality and Revolution 60developer Brianna Wu ran as a Democratic candidate in the primary election for Massachuset’s 8th Congressional District. Despite her political inexperience, Wu garnered 22.9% of the district’s vote (16,878 votes out of a total of 73,582), but ultimately lost the…

summary: Sooo whats all the hype about people hating on Brie Larson? I looked it up and I found videos on youtube that basically trashed...
question: Sooo whats all the hype about people hating on Brie Larson? I looked it up and I found videos on youtube that basically trashed her and I gave up on search engines altogether!!
answer:
As far as I know- She pretty much just stated that there needs to be more people of colour taking the lead when it comes to press her press conferences because apparently, it was almost always white males who were taking the lead in asking questions, writing the articles etc.


“ About a year ago, I started paying attention to what my press days looked like and the critics reviewing movies, and noticed it appeared to be overwhelmingly white male,” Larson told Marie Claire interviewer Keah Brown, a disabled journalist the actress handpicked for the gig. “So, I spoke to Dr. Stacy Smith at the USC Annenberg Inclusion Initiative, who put together a study to confirm that. Moving forward, I decided to make sure my press days were more inclusive. After speaking with you, the film critic Valerie Complex and a few other women of color, it sounded like across the board they weren’t getting the same opportunities as others. When I talked to the facilities that weren’t providing it, they all had different excuses.”


Apparently, that translates to “Brie Larson hates men” to the white male.

It’s pretty pathetic really. She’s a good egg!

https://www.thedailybeast.com/how-brie-larsons-captain-marvel-made-angry-white-men-lose-their-damn-minds

summary: I’ve seen Captain Marvel!
body:
I’ve seen Captain Marvel!

And god it was so fucking good, I loved every. Single. Part. She snapped. She’s everything I’ve ever wanted to be. And don’t get me started on Goose! Or the mid-credit scene! I was shoooooooooook to my core. God definitely is a woman.

summary: Captain Marvel Spoiler Tag Info
title: Captain Marvel Spoiler Tag Info
body:
From here on in I will be tagging everything relating to Captain Marvel with the highly imaginative, ‘captain marvel spoilers’. Add it to your blacklist or do whatever it is you need to do if you’d rather not see the spoilers!

I’ll keep doing this until the film is widely available everywhere, usually about a week after it is out on home release in the UK (because we never get the bluray first, ever).

summary: As a gal who’s really pumped for Captain Marvel, let me just say this to all the people bashing it for having a female...
body:
As a gal who’s really pumped for Captain Marvel, let me just say this to all the people bashing it for having a female protagonist: people like you are why this is my first Marvel movie in theaters.


I have always loved superheroes, though I never got into comics—things like the Incredibles, Danny Phantom, and the Powerpuff Girls were my jam as a kid. But comics always seemed so intimidating to me. When I was a kid, it was because I didn’t know when to start, and when I was a teen, it was because I was always convinced comic book fanboys would freeze me out for being a woman. I was convinced that just seeing a Marvel movie would make a ton of people call me a “fake fan,” even though they were box office smashes.

To be fair, the Internet didn’t give me a lot of reasons to believe my fears were irrational.


Nine years. I went nine years wanting to see these movies, but never working up the courage. My roommate freshman year was the biggest female Marvel movie fan I’ve ever seen, and she never let a single man’s thought get in the way of the things she enjoyed. If you saw her, you might think she’s just another cringey Loki fangirl, but in a small way, I envied her for doing what she loved.


The fact that people would call her cringey is, I think, the problem, but that’s a discussion for another day.


I’ve already seen and heard about what movies like Wonder Woman and Captain Marvel do for girls, and I feel that. It brings me back to when I was a little girl, watching Teen Titans before my parents told me it was too violent. It wasn’t their fault, it was just the way society was then—action movies and cartoons just can’t be for girls. I feel like, if I was born among today’s children, I’d be one of the little girls pretending to be Captain Marvel. (Even as an adult, I think, “I’ve got short blonde hair like her, so if I like this movie, I can get the cosplay jacket when it goes on sale!”).

I honestly can’t wait for a day when we get a movie like Into the Spider Verse for POC women (even a stand-alone movie with one of the Black Panther ladies would be amazing), but it’s important to look at it this way—at least society’s moving a tiny bit closer now. Even if it’s just the fact that I’d let my future 9-year-old daughter watch superhero cartoons when my parents didn’t. To me, though, it’s the rabid fans that are keeping it from moving further.

You know what finally got me to watch Marvel movies? My boyfriend. And this time, it’s not one of those cases where the girl just watches something the guy likes to make him happy. It’s a case where I learn he loves these movies and I tell him I have always wanted to watch them. Where he tells me that being a fan shouldn’t mean keeping others from doing the things you love. That I shouldn’t let other people stop me from doing what I love. Even if it would have been some random person at a con telling me that, I still would have watched all those movies because I genuinely feel that is what I wanted someone to tell me all along.

It sounds cheesy, but I’m of the belief that even though keeping someone from things they love (or might love someday) seems small, it can impact them in big ways. And life’s too short to keep people from watching a movie because you don’t believe in what it’s saying.


I’m going to see Captain Marvel in two days. And, for some odd reason, just thinking about that is exciting. Just saying that, to me, almost feels like growth.

reblog.comment:
As a gal who’s really pumped for Captain Marvel, let me just say this to all the people bashing it for having a female protagonist: people like you are why this is my first Marvel movie in theaters.


I have always loved superheroes, though I never got into comics—things like the Incredibles, Danny Phantom, and the Powerpuff Girls were my jam as a kid. But comics always seemed so intimidating to me. When I was a kid, it was because I didn’t know when to start, and when I was a teen, it was because I was always convinced comic book fanboys would freeze me out for being a woman. I was convinced that just seeing a Marvel movie would make a ton of people call me a “fake fan,” even though they were box office smashes.

To be fair, the Internet didn’t give me a lot of reasons to believe my fears were irrational.


Nine years. I went nine years wanting to see these movies, but never working up the courage. My roommate freshman year was the biggest female Marvel movie fan I’ve ever seen, and she never let a single man’s thought get in the way of the things she enjoyed. If you saw her, you might think she’s just another cringey Loki fangirl, but in a small way, I envied her for doing what she loved.


The fact that people would call her cringey is, I think, the problem, but that’s a discussion for another day.


I’ve already seen and heard about what movies like Wonder Woman and Captain Marvel do for girls, and I feel that. It brings me back to when I was a little girl, watching Teen Titans before my parents told me it was too violent. It wasn’t their fault, it was just the way society was then—action movies and cartoons just can’t be for girls. I feel like, if I was born among today’s children, I’d be one of the little girls pretending to be Captain Marvel. (Even as an adult, I think, “I’ve got short blonde hair like her, so if I like this movie, I can get the cosplay jacket when it goes on sale!”).

I honestly can’t wait for a day when we get a movie like Into the Spider Verse for POC women (even a stand-alone movie with one of the Black Panther ladies would be amazing), but it’s important to look at it this way—at least society’s moving a tiny bit closer now. Even if it’s just the fact that I’d let my future 9-year-old daughter watch superhero cartoons when my parents didn’t. To me, though, it’s the rabid fans that are keeping it from moving further.

You know what finally got me to watch Marvel movies? My boyfriend. And this time, it’s not one of those cases where the girl just watches something the guy likes to make him happy. It’s a case where I learn he loves these movies and I tell him I have always wanted to watch them. Where he tells me that being a fan shouldn’t mean keeping others from doing the things you love. That I shouldn’t let other people stop me from doing what I love. Even if it would have been some random person at a con telling me that, I still would have watched all those movies because I genuinely feel that is what I wanted someone to tell me all along.

It sounds cheesy, but I’m of the belief that even though keeping someone from things they love (or might love someday) seems small, it can impact them in big ways. And life’s too short to keep people from watching a movie because you don’t believe in what it’s saying.


I’m going to see Captain Marvel in two days. And, for some odd reason, just thinking about that is exciting. Just saying that, to me, almost feels like growth.

blog.name: thegetawaywriter
blog.title: The Getaway Writer
blog.description: Masterlist Fic Recs Asks are open / Requests are closed This is a fanfic blog, I decided to share my writing.

summary:
Update:

Oh look, a sneak peek from a Chris Evans x reader oneshot I will publish tomorrow. 
 It’s up, it’s called Mrs. Evans.

...
body:
Update: Oh look, a sneak peek from a Chris Evans x reader oneshot I will publish tomorrow. It’s up, it’s called Mrs. Evans.

You teased him under his shirt with your fingers, where his tattoos where, driving him mad, he grunted in response, you proceed to play with your fingers slowly going down on his abs stopping at the waistline of his sweatpants. He moaned in response, you took of his shirt and pushed him back to bed, he pulled you with him, making you giggle in response.

I’m watching Captain Marvel tomorrow night, but I promise this will be a spoiler free blog, also how long after it is ok to share stuff about that movie?
